reviewText: Great Rockumentary with video & commentary with all the Airplane band members. It's so great to see how much they loved the 60's and how much they helped influence that generation. Rock and Roll Hall of Fame members and they're all still alive.........a great video that brings back lots of memories and insights into what it was all about . I didn't realize how often they were on the Smother's Brothers TV Show (several video/music clips of them on that show). The commentary is with the band members NOW, while the music video is all with the band back in the 60's. A must-have if you're an Airplane fan.

reviewText: I guess I developed my appreciation for the Jefferson Airplane during my college years (1977-1981). I'm no child of the sixties, but my uncle went to Woodstock, and like many college students I learned of the magical powers of certain hallucinogenic substances. There is some ineffable quality in Jefferson Airplane's music that lends itself well to the psychedelic experience, and anyone who knows where I'm coming from ought to get this DVD. Apparently produced under the auspices of Airplane guitarist Jorma Kaukonen, this disc captures some of the magic of the San Francisco music scene, circa 1965-1972, and the pivotal role Jefferson Airplane played therein. That the members of the band are still alive and still relatively LUCID is nothing short of amazing, but if you are looking for dish, you won't find much here; there's nothing in the interviews that hints of the acrimony that sometimes flared during the band's heyday. But the musical performances: WOW! Where did they dig up some of these films? And how did they preserve them so well? Particularly fascinating for me is the performance of "It's No Secret," featuring the band's FIRST female vocalist, Signe Anderson. Her presence is altogether different from that of her successor, Grace Slick, but there's something about the quality of her voice that always intrigued me. The performance is a heady mixture of exultant vocals, jubilant dancing in the audience, and of course those very trippy liquid light shows that Ms. Anderson's first husband was apparently responsible for. I don't think you can overestimate the archival value of "Fly Jefferson Airplane." So break out the stash, slap this disc on the DVD player, and take a little TRIP back in time ....

reviewText: Great story about the history of Jefferson Airplane, the band members (with interviews as they look back), & a little history about the hippy, counter-culture, protest (however you want to refer to it) generation around San Francisco in the 60's & 70's. I found after watching this, I had a much bigger appreciation of the band on a musical / instrumental level - but not so much appreciation lyrically - but then again I'm a right-wing conservative!! Still - a GREAT source of information & inspiration!!
summary: Great story about the history of Jefferson Airplane

reviewText: Fantastic ! What a delight to revisit the music and the artists that made it. Jefferson Airplane were always a mystical kind of band bordering on hallucinogenic stuff but the music was mostly tight and some of their trademark songs could only have been done by them. This DVD is constantly engaging and provides an insider's view to this mercurial band and it's creations. Recommended for all Airplane fans and any lover of the sixties music.

reviewText: You know what they say, if you grew up in the 60's and remember that time, you're lying, you weren't there. I just got a brain cell to kick in! I recall playing White Rabbit on a juke box and an old guy saying, "what's wrong with that woman?" I THINK I SAID, "Folks like you".Seriously, buy the DVD and try to capture your youth.

reviewText: Oh sweet and loving God, thank you, thank you, THANK-YOU!!!  Jefferson Airplane have finally done it!!!  One of the most beautiful, mysterious, profound and revolutionary rock bands in history has finally been properly and gloriously documented on DVD.Could there be a Holier Grail for any lover of the REAL music of the `60's than this DVD, which is absolutely chock full of nearly every significant bit of Airplane performance footage in existence?  This isn't a reunion, this isn't a comeback.  This is genuine vintage footage; real, authentic, edgy, brilliant, fiery, psychedelic and soul-tattooing and I LOVE IT!!!For twenty years after the end of WWII, mainstream society tried to find a way to get comfortable with the Atomic Bomb.  Somehow, it was thought, "normalcy" could still prevail.  We thought that if we were out grilling red meat in the backyard one evening and suddenly saw a surprise sunrise, that we'd all just calmly go down into the concrete bunker next to the cabana, taking along our little umbrella drinks and making sure to help mom in her cocktail dress and heels.  We'd just buy a big can of radiation-reflecting hairspray and cake on the SPF 10,000 sun block with a trowel, and everything could go on just like before, right?  After all, the white men with crew cuts and dark blue polyester suits had everything under control and were going to take care of us.  How could anything bad happen?By 1965, there were masses and masses of people who were whispering, saying, shouting and finally screaming, "F-K THAT!" and Jefferson Airplane was one of the beacons, one of the lighthouses that these people turned to in search of new ways to think and new ways to be.  They were anti-establishment and counter-culture by choice and by conscience, because the "establishment" had brought everyone to the brink of incineration with the cooperation of a straight culture that was really just an attempt to normalize the official madness of the cold war.  I believe that, whether they know it or not, Jefferson Airplane and others like them helped prevent a nuclear "exchange" between Russia and America, and I also think that they and their peers played a large part in ending the crime against humanity that was happening in Vietnam.It doesn't matter who you are, you need to own this DVD.  It is a musically beautiful, socially relevant, mind-blowing image of a band that was fighting for all of our lives, and that was calling on all of us to have the courage to love without fear, love without hesitating, love without keeping score and most of all to love ourselves enough to demand peace and justice.

reviewText: I expected better from this DVD, Most of the film footage is poor quality of the band and more footage should of been shown of song performances . There are some very good  songs  on this DVD  about 3 that really stand out for me, the rest are mediocre songs of not much interest. Jefferson Airplane was a band that had some really good songs and the rest were just so-so. Though I guess this is better than nothing at all ?, It would be nice to have some complete concert footage from this band from the 1960s on DVD. These Clips are OK but this could of been better.

reviewText: I bought this DVD after months of debating. I love Jefferson Airplane, and saw them live as often as I could in the '60's & early '70's before they crashed and burned. I knew in advance I was in for some corny, trippy television. But at least the music would be good. Fly Jefferson Airplane delivers some classic moments - Grace in black face doing the black power salute on the Smothers Brothers, the infamous NYC rooftop performance when House at Pooneil Corners shut down the streets of Manhattan and NYPD broke up the party, running up and down hills in the park to Martha. This was how rock music was delivered in the days before MTV and music videos, when we were glued to mainstream television broadcasts to see our heroes and heroines in our living rooms. If you love the band, want a sense of history, gather some snippets of insight from the members, buy this DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Airplane was the first concert I every saw in '67, and I have been a major rocker ever since. JA was just a totally awesome Band, that you really had to be there and experience their concerts in the late '60's to appreciate how incredible they were, and what a unique period of time that the late `60's was in history. JA's albums didn't do justice to their live performances! I am so glad they came out this DVD. Excellent footage, interviews, and very well produced. Highly recommend to anyone who "lived" through the 60's scene, or wants to learn about it.
summary: Awesome DVD, of a Awesome Band, of a Awesome Time in History
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a difficult video for me to review in a way. Hardcore fans of the Jefferson Airplane may as well skip over this one, as my comments are directed more toward other newcomers like myself.At 44, I am a few years too young to really be part of the JA's generation, having bought my first rock album in 1974. It's amazing how even a few, short, years can place you in an entirely different musical generation. I grew-up on the progressive rock virtuoso's and hard rock bands of the 70's, and even by 1975, the "hippie generation" seemed as old and quaint as Hair Bands did by 1994. Things change fast. In the last few years, I've tried to expand my musical palette a bit, and have begun seeking-out bands and genres that I missed over the years. A friend told me that "Fly Jefferson Airplane" was an excellent way to become acquainted with the bands music and philosophy, in a relatively concise way.Well first things first. If you are expecting a documentary, telling the history and story of the bands career, you will be disappointed. This is really just a collection of (complete) performance clips alternating between interviews with the band members. If you are interested in learning more about the band's history, you will probably want to try one of the books available.As a sampling of what the band was about musically, and performance-wise, this isn't a bad place to begin, with caveats. The video, for one, only covers the band's 60's period, the latest clip being from 1970. Performance clips include the expected hits "White Rabbit" and "Somebody to Love" (the only ones I had been familar-with)taken from television appearances, as well as actual concert film clips of lessser-known LP tracks.Although it was interesting to see the band play, the sound quality of these vintage clips was understandably not so good, especially the concert footage, making much of the band's sometimes less-than-concise jamming difficult to make-out.In other words, if you're new to the bands music, you may want to borrow a CD or two, to better hear what they are actually playing first.As a non-fan, i was suprised by how raw Marty Balin's vocals were compared to the 70's crooning I was used-to. Marty could actually deliver a good ballsy, rock vocal. Who knew?I was also suprised at what a charismatic front-woman Grace Slick turned out to be. She is one of those rare people that can command your attention without doing much other than stand there singing.Unfortunately, I can't say that from what I heard, the Airplane's music was quite my cup of tea. It was chock-a-block with off-key harmonies, barely-there arrangements, and guitar notes bent wayyy out of pitch, so if you are a "muso" type that like their music played in a more "technically proficient" way, this probably won't really move you either.  However, I will say this for them, their music is very unique, and sounds like no other band I've ever heard. There's no way you could ever confuse them with anyone else, and that might be the highest praise.After all, Les Paul once said:"You may have all you licks and chops down...but can your mother recognise you on the radio?"Judged by that standard, I would say Les would be pleased.Overall this is probably a terrific video for fans, but the iffy sound quality makes it not the best introduction to the band's music. Although, it is a lot cheaper than buying a career box-set, and the interviews are interesting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The CD is done well, but  . . . . there is too much talking and breakaways from the music. Most of the songs are taken from live concerts. If you really enjoy the Airplane and want more of a documentary/musiic DVD,then you will enjoy this. I would have preferered just the concert. It does give you a lot of info about the songs and the group members. It was enjoyable. The sound is good and the visual is clear. The project was wellproduced. It starts with the early songs and moves towards the later hits. It contains just 13 songs. My favorites are It's No Secret, White Rabbit and Embryonic Journey. The CD  clocks in at 111 minutes with the majoritybeing talking.
summary: For the Die Hard Airplane fans

reviewText: it was just the right balance as far as informative interviews with all the bandmembers and uncut, unterupted vintage music clips of the airplane performing their songs at various venues and tv appearances from the 60's. all i can say is , wow, what an awesome band! early clip for 'it's no secret' being performed by balin with original singer signe anderson is especially revelatory. also love the clips and performances of 'martha', 'crown of creation', 'plastic fantastic lover' and 'we can be together' as well as 'lather'. if you love psychedelic rock and you're not onboard the airplane, you will certainly buy a round trip airfare here!

reviewText: I purchased this DVD just before hearing of the death of Spencer Dryden, which only served to underline sadly what a timely release this is before the demise of any other group members.And what a great release it is taking in chronolgical order the history of the group with all members of the great JA (plus a few others notably Joey Covington & "Marvellous" Maurice Ieracci) telling it how it really was in various recently recorded snippets. The development of the band's music from initial powerful electric folk to on the edge improvising and political stances is well captured (the live performance of "The Ballad of you & Me & Pooneil" at the Family Dogg being the standout). But what makes this more than just a video of live historical TV and movie performances is its structure provides a snapshot of the SF late 1960s era plus documenting the many different and powerful personalities. Balin comes across as simple songwriter and effective singer; Kantner complicated songwriter and sci-fi freak both being well matched by the dominant Grace Slick (chosen to give them an edge locally against Big Brother with Janis Joplin) who clearly was then the spark to all the others, including getting rid of Bill Graham as their manager and pushing on the three great musicians of Dryden (getting the drum seat after Skip Spence started being unreliant, despite being jazz orinetated, from LA and older than the others as Slick gleefully covers in her lyrical inspiration for "Lather"), and the guitar powerhouse of Kaukonen and Cassady, the latter coming across in joint interviews as being much more attuned and closer than subsequent events might have indicated.The best San Francisco 1960s music related video releases I have seen to date.
Title: N/A

reviewText: And the truth is, that this is a superb DVD which, if anything, exceeded my wildest expectations. The picture quality is superb, the song selection is excellent, and the most important thing for me, is that these are all complete performances. I have seen so many documentary-style DVDs in which there are only fragments of songs between interviews, but here we have full songs, folks. The interviews themselves are superb and the archived footage of the band really gives you the ultimate backstage pass to one of the best bands in the history of the music industry.
